column4: Hi all, I have a NAS drive and I want to sync my files onto it. I have installed luckybackup and grcync, but grcync doesn't recognise my smb drive and in luckybackup I can't find where I can exclude directories. Does anyone know a better way for me to setup my NAS so it is more compatible or is there a program that will let me synch better?
running ubuntu 10
how did you mount the drive?
Places > Computer > Network > and then dragged and dropped the NAS onto the "Places" on the left of the screen (under desktop, file system, network, etc)
so now when I open it up, I get "smb://x.x.x.x/" on the location bar.
that might not be enough for the backup apps. Nautilus reads smb:// just fine, but those apps probably cant. you need to mound it with cifs.
cifs? (noob here)
add to /etc/fstab as root:    //NAS-IP_or_hostname /mount-point cifs uid=user,credentials=/home/user/.credentials.cifs 0 0
Thanks for that, I'll give it a go..
I've found th file and have copied it to my desktop so that I could edit it, but how do I put it back into the /etc as the file there is read only.
gksudo gedit /etc/fstab
that will edit it in place as root, so be careful not to mess with the other lines. ;)
so should this take effect immediately, if so, I have done something wrong..
do I just add it at the bottom of the file?
when you're done you do a sudo mount -a in a terminal. Let me know if you get any errors.
yes.
No errors, but also no apparent results :(
